content.instruction:
Introduction to the reading of the novel Foster

Enjoy exploring a local universe:

Irish author Claire Keegan issued the novel Foster in 2010. The young girl Petal moves to the Kinsellas, while her mother prepares for another childbirth.
During her stay Petal encounters new aspects of life and when she returns to her family she has changed.

In modules 1, 2 and 3 you will get the opportunity to elaborate on your personal reading by responding to general tasks. In each module you will write the notes you need to complete assignment 4.

microhint.text: A protagonist is the leading character or one of the major characters in a short story, novel, play, film etc.

onClick.NOTE: Alle id'er og klasser angives med mellemrum - ligesom i 'target' for dropdowns

microhint.text:
Characters can be presented in two ways:
  1. Direct characterization tells the reader directly what sort of person a character is.
  2. Indirect characterization forces a reader to draw conclusions about what the character is like by what the character says or does.
    Characterization is about a literary figure’s: Name, age, appearance, thoughts, feelings, maturity, behaviour, education, social status, relations to other people or a place, development etc.

cmdObj.add: 'Aye, Da says. It’s the feeding them that’s the trouble. There’s no appetite like a child’s and believe you me, this one is no different'

Physical setting is about: Place, geography, season, weather etc.
Social setting is about: Social class, circumstances etc.

Time is about: When, a few minutes or a lifetime? Period of history etc.

microhint.text:
Symbolism is the use of symbols to signify ideas and qualities by giving them symbolic meanings that are different from their literal sense.
Something represents something else to give an entirely different meaning that is deeper and more significant.

Symbols shift their meanings depending on the context they are used in. A chain may stand for union as well as imprisonment. Symbolic meaning is understood by when, where, and how it is used. It also depends on who reads the work.
The dove is a symbol of peace. A red rose stands for love. Black is a symbol that represents evil or death.

microhint.text:
Characterisation is the representation of persons (or other beings or creatures) in narrative and dramatic works of art. This representation may include direct methods like the attribution of qualities in description or commentary, and indirect (or 'dramatic') methods inviting readers to infer qualities from characters' actions, dialogue, or appearance. Such a personage is called a character
Kilde: ”Håndbog til dansk”

microhint.text: By using contrasts and dichotomies an author is able to establish a conflict in either characters or setting. “Light – dark,” “happy-gloomy,” “calm – desperate,” “sun – rain,” “city – nature” are examples of contrasts which can be used to observe conflict and development in characters.

microhint.text:
In your analysis it is often fruitful to consider the effect of language – whether it:
  • Is simple or complex (long sentences, complex vocabulary or not)
  • Is straightforward or figurative (It is raining / A river of tears flows from the sky)
  • Mirrors the protagonist’s state of mind (short, fast sentences mirror Daphne’s panic attack in the mall).

microhint.text:
The tone of a text is the feel established by the narrative voice. The tone can be created in many different ways: through the choice of motif, theme, setting, type of characters, diction, overall use of language, etc. The tone can be ironic, sarcastic, humorous, comic, tongue-in-cheek, intense, understated, hostile, pathetic, tragic, etc.

Setting, theme, tone, language and diction are examples of literary devices used to create a certain mood (also referred to as atmosphere) meant to evoke certain feelings in the reader. For instance, the mood in a text can be peaceful, joyous, sinister, tense etc.

microhint.text:
The protagonist is at the center of the story, makes the key decisions, and experiences the consequences of those decisions. The protagonist is the primary agent propelling the story forward, and is often the character who faces the most significant obstacles. If a story contains a subplot, or is a narrative made up of several stories, then each subplot may have its own protagonist.
Source: ”Wikipedia.org”

microhint.text: Belonging means to feel at home. On the contrary estrangement emerges when a literary character ceases to maintain a connection to the familiar world that surrounds her and when she is exposed to an unfamiliar world. Daphne in Baglady exemplifies an estranged character.

microhint.text: Considering the title of a text will most often reveal what the story is about on a thematic level. This is often done indirectly by allusion. Therefore, the title must be interpreted.
